sen.j: 吉子女王（よしこじょおう、文化 (元号)元年9月25日 (旧暦)（1804年10月28日） - 明治26年（1893年）1月27日）は、幕末から明治時代の皇族出身女性。
sen.e: Princess Yoshiko (October 28, 1804 - January 27, 1893) was born into the Imperial family and lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.
Princess Yoshiko (October 28, 1804 - January 27, 1893), who was from the Imperial family, lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.
sen.cmt: 誤訳です。Was born into→who was from に訂正しました。
sen.e: Princess Yoshiko (October 28, 1804 - January 27, 1893), who was from the Imperial family, lived from the end of the Edo period to the Meiji period.

sen.j: 有栖川宮織仁親王の九女。
sen.e: She was the ninth daughter of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito.
She was the ninth daughter of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito.
She was the ninth daughter of Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito.

sen.j: 生母は側室の安藤清子。
sen.e: Her real mother was Kiyoko ANDO, a concubine.
Her real mother was Kiyoko ANDO who was a nobleman's concubine.
sen.cmt: 表現訂正です。Who was a nobleman'sを追加しました。
sen.e: Her real mother was Kiyoko ANDO who was a nobleman's concubine.

sen.j: 水戸藩主・徳川斉昭正室（御簾中）となる。
sen.e: She became the lawful wife of Nariaki TOKUGAWA who was the lord of the Mito Domain, and Gorenju (title of honor for lawful wife of an aristocrat as daijin, cabinet minister and kugyo, court noble).
She became the lawful wife of Nariaki TOKUGAWA who was the lord of the Mito Domain, and Gorenju (title of honor for lawful wife of an aristocrat as daijin, cabinet minister and kugyo, court noble).
She became the lawful wife of Nariaki TOKUGAWA who was the lord of the Mito Domain, and Gorenju (title of honor for lawful wife of an aristocrat as daijin, cabinet minister and kugyo, court noble).

sen.j: 幼称は登美宮（とみのみや）。
sen.e: Her childhood name was Tomi no Miya.
Her childhood name was Tomi no Miya.
Her childhood name was Tomi no Miya.

sen.j: 院号は貞芳院。
sen.e: Her ingo, a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing, was Teihoin.
Her ingo (the title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Teihoin.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。Ingoの説明文にtheと()を追加しました。
sen.e: Her ingo (the title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) was Teihoin.

sen.j: 水戸藩伝統の儒教に則り、没後文明夫人と諡される。
sen.e: She conformed to Confucianism in the tradition of the Mito Domain and was called Bunmei Fujin (a lady of civilization) as a posthumous title.
In accordance with the tradition of Confucianism of the Mito Domain, she was called Bunmei Fujin (the lady of civilization) after her death.
sen.cmt: 誤訳及び文法ミスです。In accordance with the tradition of Confucianismに追加訂正しました。as a posthumous title→after her deathに訂正しました。
sen.e: In accordance with the tradition of Confucianism of the Mito Domain, she was called Bunmei Fujin (the lady of civilization) after her death.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 27歳のとき、当時としては結婚適齢期を遥かに過ぎた年齢になってから徳川斉昭との婚約がまとまり、江戸に降嫁。
sen.e: When she was 27 years old, which was beyond marriageable age in those days, she became engaged to Nariaki TOKUGAWA and went to Edo for Koka (marriage of an Imperial princess to a subject).

When she was 27 years old, although it was beyond the marriageable age at that time, she was able to get engaged to Nariaki TOKUGAWA; She went to Edo for Koka (marriage of an Imperial princess to a subject).
sen.cmt: 自然な文章に訂正しました。Which→although it, In those days→at that time
sen.e: When she was 27 years old, although it was beyond the marriageable age at that time, she was able to get engaged to Nariaki TOKUGAWA; She went to Edo for Koka (marriage of an Imperial princess to a subject).

sen.j: この婚約は姉・楽宮喬子女王の肝入りで決まったと言われる。
sen.e: This marriage was arranged through the good offices of Princess Sazanomiya Takako, who was her older sister.
It is said that this marriage was arranged because her older sister, Princess Sazanomiya Takako, had greatly supported her to settle the arrangement.
sen.cmt: 訳抜けです。It is said that, "肝いり"の訳を訂正しました。
sen.e: It is said that this marriage was arranged because her older sister, Princess Sazanomiya Takako, had greatly supported her to settle the arrangement.

sen.j: また、婚約の勅許を下した仁孝天皇は、「水戸は先代以来、政教能く行われ、世々勤王の志厚しとかや、宮の為には良縁なるべし」と満足したといわれる。
sen.e: Also, Emperor Ninko, who gave the permission for the marriage, said, "The Mito Domain has been dedicated to both religion and politics since the time of the former head and has had high loyalty to the Emperor for generations, so this marriage is good for Tomi no Miya," and was satisfied with the marriage.

When the Emperor Ninko gave permission for the marriage, he was satisfied with it, saying as following: "Because the Mito Domain have been dedicated to both religions and politics since the period of their predecessors, and have been highly loyal to the emperors for generations, this marriage should be good for the Princess.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスと「」内の訳を訂正しました。
sen.e: When the Emperor Ninko gave permission for the marriage, he was satisfied with it, saying as following: "Because the Mito Domain have been dedicated to both religions and politics since the period of their predecessors, and have been highly loyal to the emperors for generations, this marriage should be good for the Princess.

sen.j: 斉昭との間に長男・徳川慶篤、七男・徳川慶喜を儲ける。
sen.e: She bore Nariaki's first son, Yoshiatsu TOKUGAWA and his seventh son, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
She had some children of Nariaki, such as the first son, Yoshiatsu TOKUGAWA and the seventh son, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。She bore→she had some children, such as
sen.e: She had some children of Nariaki, such as the first son, Yoshiatsu TOKUGAWA and the seventh son, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 他に男子1名女子1名を儲けたが夭折している。
sen.e: She also had one more son and daughter but they died at an early age.
She also had another son and one daughter; However, they died young.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。died at an early age→died young
sen.e: She also had another son and one daughter; However, they died young.

sen.j: 艶福家の夫によく仕え、庶子の教育にも目を配り「賢夫人」としての名声が生前より高かった。
sen.e: She served her husband who was a ladies man, kept an eye on the education of even his illegitimate children, and earned a good reputation as a wise wife.
As she was tolerant with her husband who had affairs and she even looked after education of his illegitimate children, she was well reputed to be a wise wife.
sen.cmt: 自然な文章になるよう訂正しました。Served→was tolerant with, ladies' man→who had affairs, kept an eye on→looked after, earned a good reputation as a wise wife→was well reputed to be a wise wife
sen.e: As she was tolerant with her husband who had affairs and she even looked after education of his illegitimate children, she was well reputed to be a wise wife.

sen.j: 万延元年（1860年）に幽閉中の夫・斉昭が死去すると、直ちに落飾、「貞芳院」と名乗る。
sen.e: In 1860, when her husband, Nariaki died under confinement, she immediately became a Buddhist nun and announced herself as "Teihoin."
In 1860, once her husband, Nariaki died under confinement, she became a Buddhist nun and called herself as "Teihoin."
In 1860, once her husband, Nariaki died under confinement, she became a Buddhist nun and called herself as "Teihoin."

sen.j: しかし、12代将軍徳川家慶の正室の妹であり、宮家出身の彼女の動向は井伊直弼をはじめとする「南紀派」の幕府首脳には恐れられていたらしい。
sen.e: However, it is believed that Naosuke II and other leaders of the Nanki group (group supporting Yoshitomi from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family) were fearful of her actions because she was the younger sister of the lawful wife of the twelfth shogun, Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA and was from the Imperial family.

Nevertheless, it is believed that Naosuke II and other leaders of the Nanki group (the group supporting Yoshitomi from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family) were fearful of her actions, because she was the younger sister of the lawful wife of the twelfth shogun, Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA and besides she was from the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: 自然な文章になるよう、単語を訂正・追加しました。
sen.e: Nevertheless, it is believed that Naosuke II and other leaders of the Nanki group (the group supporting Yoshitomi from the Kisyu-Tokugawa family) were fearful of her actions, because she was the younger sister of the lawful wife of the twelfth shogun, Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA and besides she was from the Imperial family.

sen.j: 病弱だったといわれる長男・慶篤の後見を務め、夫の遺志であった慶喜の将軍擁立に尽力したと言われる。
sen.e: She acted as guardian of the first son, Yoshiatsu, who was believed to suffer poor health and she made efforts to help Yoshinobu to become shogun by following her husband's will.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It is said that she was in charge of being a guardian of her first son, Yoshiatsu who seemed in poor health; She made great efforts to help Yoshinobu to become Shogun, which was also her husband's will.
sen.cmt: 訳抜けです。It is said that 自然な文章になるよう、単語を訂正・追加しました。
sen.e: It is said that she was in charge of being a guardian of her first son, Yoshiatsu who seemed in poor health; She made great efforts to help Yoshinobu to become Shogun, which was also her husband's will.

sen.j: しかし、慶篤は藩内の混乱による心労で早世、皮肉にも慶喜は最後の将軍となり、実家の有栖川宮熾仁親王に追討される身の上となる。
sen.e: However, Yoshiatsu died prematurely from worrying over the internal chaos of the domain, while Yoshinobu became the last shogun and was hunted down by Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito who was a member of his own family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Nevertheless, while Yoshiatsu died young due to worries over political chaos inside the domain, ironically Yoshinobu became the last Shogun; However, Yoshinobu ended up being hunted down by Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito who was a member of his own family.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。Died prematurely→died young, from worrying over the internal chaos of→due to worries over political chaos inside 訳抜けなのでironicallyを追加しました。Ended up beingを追加しました。
sen.e: Nevertheless, while Yoshiatsu died young due to worries over political chaos inside the domain, ironically Yoshinobu became the last Shogun; However, Yoshinobu ended up being hunted down by Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito who was a member of his own family.

sen.j: 明治維新後は、若死にした慶篤の跡を嗣いだ徳川昭武の世話となり、余生を送った。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, she was taken care of by Akitake TOKUGAWA who took over Yoshiatsu's position after Yoshiatsu's premature death, and spent the rest of her life there.
After the Meiji Restoration, she was taken care of by Akitake TOKUGAWA who took over Yoshiatsu's position after he had died young; she spent the rest of her life at Akitake's.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。after Yoshiatsu's premature death, and spent the rest of her life there→after he had died young; she spent the rest of her life at Akitake's
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, she was taken care of by Akitake TOKUGAWA who took over Yoshiatsu's position after he had died young; she spent the rest of her life at Akitake's.

sen.j: 別家に養子に出た慶喜との同居は武家社会の慣習上出来なかったが、親しく文通を行い、頻繁に交流していた様子が残っている書簡から伺える。
sen.e: Because of samurai society customs, she couldn't live with Yoshinobu, who had been adopted by another family, but the remaining letters tell us that they communicated frequently by exchanging the letters.

Because of the customs of the samurai society at that time, she was not allowed to live with her child, Yoshinobu who had been adopted by a different family; However, the remaining letters show that she and Youshinobu closely corresponded and frequently communicated.
sen.cmt: 自然な文章になるよう、全体的に単語を訂正・追加しました。
sen.e: Because of the customs of the samurai society at that time, she was not allowed to live with her child, Yoshinobu who had been adopted by a different family; However, the remaining letters show that she and Youshinobu closely corresponded and frequently communicated.

sen.j: 長命を全うし、明治26年（1893年）に卒去。
sen.e: She had a long life and died in 1893.
She lived long and passed away in 1893.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。had a long life and died→lived long and passed awayに訂正しました。
sen.e: She lived long and passed away in 1893.

sen.j: 享年90。
sen.e: Her age of death was 90.
She died at the age of 90.
She died at the age of 90.

sen.j: 墓所は水戸藩墓所・瑞龍山（茨城県）。
sen.e: Her graveyard was located at Mt. Zuiryu in the Mito Domain (now know as Ibaraki Prefecture).
Her tomb is located at Mt. Zuiryu in the Mito Domain (the present Ibaraki Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Her graveyard was→Her tomb is 適切な表現に訂正しました。
sen.e: Her tomb is located at Mt. Zuiryu in the Mito Domain (the present Ibaraki Prefecture).

sen.j: 皇族出身であることを非常に誇りにしていた女性であったらしく、結婚後もしばらくは公家風の「おすべらかし、小袖に袴」姿で生活していたことを示す肖像画が残っている。
sen.e: It is said that she was proud of her Imperial blood and her remaining portraits tell us that she dressed in the Kuge-fu style (a court noble style) with the combination of osuberakashi, kosode, and hakama (a traditional coiffure, a kimono with short sleeves, and a formal divided skirt) for a while even after her marriage.

She seemed proud of her Imperial background; Even after her marriage, she persisted in being dressed in the Kuge-fu style (the noble court-style) which coordinated osuberakashi (the traditional coiffure), kosode (the kimono with short sleeves), and hakama (the formal divided skirt) for a while; Some of her portraits show how she wore in her daily life.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。It is said that→She seemed, ()内の分散など、全体的により適切な表現に訂正しました。
sen.e: She seemed proud of her Imperial background; Even after her marriage, she persisted in being dressed in the Kuge-fu style (the noble court-style) which coordinated osuberakashi (the traditional coiffure), kosode (the kimono with short sleeves), and hakama (the formal divided skirt) for a while; Some of her portraits show how she wore in her daily life.

sen.j: また、仕えていた女中達には自分のことを「宮様」と呼ばせ、自らは幼称であった「登美」を名乗っていた。
sen.e: Furthermore, she had her maids call her "Miya-sama" (your Imperial Highness) and announced herself as "Tomi" which was her childhood name.
Furthermore, she ordered her maids to call her "Miya-sama" (your Imperial Highness) and called herself as "Tomi" which was her childhood name.
sen.cmt: より適切な表現に訂正しました。Had her maids call→ordered her maids to call, announced→called
sen.e: Furthermore, she ordered her maids to call her "Miya-sama" (your Imperial Highness) and called herself as "Tomi" which was her childhood name.

sen.j: ちなみに肖像画に添付された斉昭の手紙などから、夫の斉昭は「吉子」と呼んでいたらしい。
sen.e: According to the Nariaki's letters attached to her portraits, he called her "Yoshiko."
According to the letters from Nariaki which were attached to her portraits, he seemed to call her "Yoshiko."
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。the Nariaki's letters attached to her portraits→the letters from Nariaki which were attached to her portraits; he called her "Yoshiko."→he seemed to call her "Yoshiko."に訂正しました。
sen.e: According to the letters from Nariaki which were attached to her portraits, he seemed to call her "Yoshiko."

sen.j: 家族
sen.e: Family
Family
Family

sen.j: 父：有栖川宮織仁親王
sen.e: Her father was Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito.
Her father was Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito.
Her father was Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Orihito.

sen.j: 兄：有栖川宮韶仁親王・梶井宮承眞法親王・輪王寺宮舜仁入道親王・知恩院宮尊超入道親王
sen.e: Her older brothers were Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Tsunahito, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kajiinomiya 承眞, priestly Imperial Prince Rinojinomiya Shunnin, priestly Imperial Prince Chioninnomiya Soncho.
sen.cmt: 「承眞」の読み不明「舜仁」の読み→http://kotobank.jp/word/%E8%88%9C%E4%BB%81%E5%85%A5%E9%81%93%E8%A6%AA%E7%8E%8B
sen.e: Her older brothers were Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Tsunahito, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kajiinomiya 承眞, priestly Imperial Prince Rinojinomiya Shunnin, priestly Imperial Prince Chioninnomiya Soncho.

Her older brothers were Imperial Prince Arisugawanomiya Tsunahito, Cloistered Imperial Prince Kajiinomiya 承眞, priestly Imperial Prince Rinojinomiya Shunnin, priestly Imperial Prince Chioninnomiya Soncho.

sen.j: 姉：喬子女王（江戸幕府12代将軍徳川家慶正室（御台所））
sen.e: Her older sister was Prince Takako who was the lawful wife of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the twelfth shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and was Midaidokoro (what she was called as a wife of a shogun).

Her older sister was Princess Takako who was the lawful wife of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the twelfth Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and who was called Midaidokoro (the wife of Shogun).
sen.cmt: 誤訳です。Prince→Princess 文法ミスです。what she was called as a wife of a shogun→who was called Midaidokoro (the wife of Shogun)に訂正しました。
sen.e: Her older sister was Princess Takako who was the lawful wife of Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, the twelfth Shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and who was called Midaidokoro (the wife of Shogun).

sen.j: 夫：徳川斉昭（第9代水戸藩主）
sen.e: Her husband was Nariaki TOKUGAWA, who was the lord of the Mito Domain.
Her husband was Nariaki TOKUGAWA, who was the lord of the Mito Domain.
Her husband was Nariaki TOKUGAWA, who was the lord of the Mito Domain.

sen.j: 子：徳川慶篤（第10代水戸藩主）
sen.e: One of her sons was Yoshiatsu TOKUGAWA, who was the tenth lord of the Mito Domain.
One of her sons was Yoshiatsu TOKUGAWA, who was the tenth lord of the Mito Domain.
One of her sons was Yoshiatsu TOKUGAWA, who was the tenth lord of the Mito Domain.

sen.j: 子：徳川慶喜（一橋家当主、江戸幕府15代将軍）
sen.e: Her other son was Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, who was the head of Hitotsubashi family and the fifteenth shogun of the Edo bakufu.
Her another son was Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, who was the head of the Hitotsubashi family and became the fifteenth Shogun of the Edo bakufu.
sen.cmt: 文法ミスです。Her other son→Her another sonに、Hitotsubashi family→the Hitotsubashi familyに訂正しました。
sen.e: Her another son was Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, who was the head of the Hitotsubashi family and became the fifteenth Shogun of the Edo bakufu.
